author: draganrakita
content: Another topic that I would like to talk about is bal over p2p aka persisting of BALs. Not sure if this was discussed previously. Have talked with the team and most logical things for us is to not serve it over eth p2p, to not store it at all.

author: jwasinger
content: if it's not served over devp2p, then BALs cannot be used for the removal of snap sync healing phase.

author: jwasinger
content: IMO it makes sense to keep and serve them for recent N blocks, so that we can greatly simplify snap sync

author: draganrakita
content: Should they be part of snap sync?

author: draganrakita
content: This is hard to enforce last N blocks, maybe having it optional could work?

author: qu0b
content: The BAL is part of the block right? So wouldn‚Äôt it be persisted and propagated the same way a block is?

author: jwasinger
content: I think just having a message to query them by block hash from a node would be nice

author: qu0b
content: You want just the BAL without the block?

author: draganrakita
content: Adding it to db will increase db footprint so we need to treat it differently, to drop it

author: qu0b
content: You want to compute them on demand?

author: draganrakita
content: Look at them like a blobs, they are used to sync then dropped.

author: qu0b
content: What is the storage impact we are talking about here?

author: qu0b
content: Will a super node or archive node treat this differently?

author: jwasinger
content: roughly 2x the current block size

author: jwasinger
content: it's significant

author: qu0b
content: Even with compression?

author: jwasinger
content: I'm not factoring compression here

author: qu0b
content: Seems a bit early to be optimizing for this imo lets first get some numbers on just storing the block with BALs?

author: qu0b
content: Maybe worth adding to the call agenda

author: draganrakita
content:
> Seems a bit early to be optimizing for this imo lets first get some numbers on just storing the block with BALs?
We talked about this in Berlin, consensus was to drop them from db, so this is nothing new and it looks logical. Discussion that i wanted to have is about p2p

author: nero_eth
content: Will put that on the agenda!

author: qu0b
content: Have we looked into the compression ratio?

author: qu0b
content: Just curious now

author: qu0b
content: The reason I said early is because imo we should focus on getting a stable devnet release from all clients where they can generate valid BALs and this seems like something we can focus on for a later devnet

author: draganrakita
content: I will need to ask, for us it could be a more effort to save it to db than to just drop it.

author: qu0b
content: I see, interesting

author: pk910
content:
It sounds strange, how can reth drop the BAL?
It is part of the block body and we don't have optional fields, so when dropping the bal at some time you'd need to recalculate it on the fly to serve api or p2p block requests?
Recalculating it seems also really expensive, as you need the prestate to distinguish between storage reads & updates?
